IMAGE-HIGH-RES CHNJC 63940 S1872-2067(21)63940-2 10.1016/S1872-2067(21)63940-2 Dalian Institute of Chemical Physics, the Chinese Academy of Sciences Fig. 1 Electrochemical synthesis of catalytic materials for energy catalysis. Fig. 2 Electrochemical procedures of applying currents and potentials for electrochemical synthesis of catalytic materials. (a) Galvanostatic mode; (b) Potentiostatic mode; (c) Cyclic voltammetry; (d) Square-wave potential pulse; (e) Coupled cyclic voltammetry and square-wave potential pulse. Fig. 3 Electrochemical deposition for synthesizing single atom catalysts. Schematic of cathodic (a) and anodic (b) deposition of Ir species over Co(OH)2 nanosheets loaded on glassy carbon in a standard three-electrode cell; HAADF-STEM images of cathodically (c) and anodically (d) deposited metal single atoms on Co(OH)2 nanosheets. Reproduced with permission from Ref. [ 88 ]. Copyright 2020, Springer Nature. Fig. 4 Synthesis of single atom catalysts under high voltage. Schematic of plasma arc formed by a 20 kV direct current (DC) supply (a), spark pulse generated by a multistage Marx circuit (b) and synthesis of Co single atom catalysts using PA and SP methods (c). Reproduced with permission from Ref. [ 69 ]. Copyright 2021, Wiley-VCH. Fig. 5 Electrochemical synthesis of spherical nanoparticles. (a) Cathodic corrosion for growing nanoparticles over a Pt wire at a direct current of −10 V in 10 mol·L−1 NaOH. Reproduced with permission from Ref. [ 49 ]. Copyright 2011, Wiley-VCH. (b) Pd nanoparticles electrodeposited potentiostatically on an Au substrate. Reproduced with permission from Ref. [ 106 ]. Copyright 2018, Wiley-VCH. (c) Synthesis procedure of carbon-supported Pt nanoparticles by applying an alternating sinusoidal potential to a Pt counter electrode. Reproduced with permission from Ref. [ 104 ]. Copyright 2020, American Chemical Society. (d) HADDF-STEM images of as-prepared and electrochemically dealloyed Cu3Pt intermetallic nanoparticles. Reproduced with permission from Ref. [ 80 ]. Copyright 2015, American Chemical Society. Fig. 6 Electrochemical synthesis of shape-controlled Pt nanoparticles. (a) Scheme of electrochemical synthesis of THH Pt nanocrystals from nanospheres; (b) SEM images and size distributions of THH Pt nanocrystals grown for 10, 30, 40 and 50 min. Scale bars, 200 nm. (c) In situ transmission electron microscopy (TEM) observation on the thermal stability of THH Pt nanocrystals. Reproduced with permission from Ref. [ 116 ]. Tel: +86-411-84379128; Fax: +86-411-84694447 Tel: +86-411-84379128 Fax: +86-411-84694447 # Corresponding author Electrocatalysis is a process dealing with electrochemical reactions in the interconversion of chemical energy and electrical energy. Precise synthesis of catalytically active nanostructures is one of the key challenges that hinder the practical application of many important energy-related electrocatalytic reactions. Compared with conventional wet-chemical, solid-state and vapor deposition synthesis, electrochemical synthesis is a simple, fast, cost-effective and precisely controllable method for the preparation of highly efficient catalytic materials. In this review, we summarize recent progress in the electrochemical synthesis of catalytic materials such as single atoms, spherical and shaped nanoparticles, nanosheets, nanowires, core-shell nanostructures, layered nanomaterials, dendritic nanostructures, hierarchically porous nanostructures as well as composite nanostructures. Fundamental aspects of electrochemical synthesis and several main electrochemical synthesis methods are discussed. Structure-performance correlations between electrochemically synthesized catalysts and their unique electrocatalytic properties are exemplified using selected examples. We offer the reader with a basic guide to the synthesis of highly efficient catalysts using electrochemical methods, and we propose some research challenges and future opportunities in this field. Graphical Abstract The electrochemical synthesis methods for the preparation of catalytically active nanostructures are briefly introduced and the unique roles of electrochemically synthesized catalysts in energy-related electrocatalytic applications are exemplified. Keywords Catalytic material Electrochemical synthesis Electrocatalytic reaction Electrodeposition Cathodic corrosion Nanostructure 1 Introduction To a large extent, economic growth and social development in the current world rely on the energy supply originally derived from conventional fossil fuels such as coal, petroleum and natural gas, as well as from emerging renewable energy sources such as solar and wind. Over the past two centuries, the utilization of fossil fuels has been increasing the concentration of atmospheric carbon dioxide (CO2), thus leading to severe environmental issues and climate change. There is an urgent need to reduce CO2 emission via developing new strategies and technologies in energy supply processes. The long-term goal of the Paris Agreement is to limit global warming to well below 2, preferably to 1.5 °C, compared to pre-industrial levels. China aims to peak its total CO2 emissions by 2030 and achieve carbon neutrality by 2060. While recently renewable energy has grown rapidly, it is still too early to completely replace the use of fossil fuels. In this context, the optimized utilization of fossil energy aiming to emit less CO2 as well as the implementation of renewable energy free of CO2 emission can serve as two parallel routes in the near future. Both routes involve the conversion of substances and energy in different forms, highlighting the key role of chemistry in addressing the energy challenge [ 1,2 ]. Catalysis, a process that alters the rate of a chemical reaction, stands at the heart of energy production and utilization, as it can improve the conversion efficiency of substances and energy [ 3 ]. Electrocatalysis is a process dealing with electrochemical reactions in the interconversion of chemical energy and electrical energy [ 4 ]. Fuel cells are the most classical scenarios in which a wide range of electrocatalytic reactions are involved, such as oxygen reduction reaction (ORR), hydrogen oxidation reaction (HOR), the electrooxidation of alcohols and hydrocarbons. In general, the fuels fed to fuel cells undergo complete oxidation/combustion to water and CO2 to produce power, while it is also likely to acquire high-value products such as hydrogen peroxide via two-electron reduction of oxygen [ 5 ] and methanol via partial oxidation of methane [ 6 ] through using appropriate catalysts and controlling suitable potentials/currents. Under electrolysis conditions, electrocatalytic reactions are designed to be driven by renewable electricity, simultaneously generating useful products and storing intermittent renewable energy. This unique feature has attracted enormous research interest from researchers in the context of CO2 emission reduction as well as carbon capture, utilization and storage (CCUS). Typical examples of such electrocatalytic reactions include water electrolysis including cathodic hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) and anodic oxygen evolution reaction (OER), CO2/CO reduction reaction (CO2/CORR), electrochemical ammonia synthesis from nitrogen, nitrogen oxides and nitrite, as well as upgrading of biomass-derived platform molecules. Recently researchers have also explored a group of new electrocatalytic reactions such as hydrogen peroxide synthesis via water oxidation, methane oxidation to oxygenates, and alkyne reduction to alkene [ 7–11 ]. Compared with traditional thermal catalysis, the hydrogen (or oxygen) species needed in electrocatalytic reduction (or oxidation) reactions are in situ generated from water under specific polarization conditions, rather than using any external reductants (or oxidants). This is particularly important for hydrogenation reactions in which H2 used in thermal catalysis usually comes from syngas via water gas shift reaction that produces substantial CO2 [ 12 ]. Moreover, electrocatalytic reactions are possible to proceed at low, even room temperature. While the overall performance of a given electrocatalytic reaction is determined by multiple factors such as potential, current, temperature, pressure, catalyst, electrolyte, electrode structure and reactor configuration [ 13–17 ], the core aspect of electrocatalysis is to develop efficient catalysts with high activity, selectivity and stability. Heterogeneous catalytic reactions occur at the interface of different phases, for instance solid-gas, solid-liquid and solid-liquid-gas interfaces [ 3 ]. The size, shape, composition, oxidation state, coordination structure, surface chemistry and near surface microenvironment of catalysts often play decisive roles in improving electrocatalytic performances [ 18–20 ], therefore, the rational design and synthesis of catalytically active nanostructures is of great importance. Over the past few decades, the remarkable advances in nanoscience and nanotechnology have enabled a variety of methods for the synthesis of catalytic materials with tunable compositions and morphologies. The most widely used one is wet-chemical synthesis, a bottom-up approach using liquid-phase precursors in aqueous or organic solutions to produce a broad range of nanomaterials [ 21–24 ]. The wet-chemical synthesis techniques include impregnation, precipitation, deposition, hydrothermal synthesis, solvothermal synthesis, sol-gel synthesis, as well as colloidal synthesis that provides unique opportunities to control the size, shape and composition of nanoparticles and nanocrystals [ 23 ]. Solid-state synthesis shows unique ability in preparing metal- and nitrogen-doped carbon materials, porous metal catalysts as well as perovskite oxide catalysts [ 25–27 ]. Physical vapor deposition (PVD), chemical vapor deposition (CVD) and atomic layer deposition (ALD) techniques provide alternative methods to produce ultrathin films, carbon-supported NPs and finely dispersed metal particles as model or real catalysts in electrocatalytic reactions [ 28–31 ]. While these synthesis methods have produced a large number of nanostructures with excellent electrocatalytic performances, they suffer either from the difficulty in precisely controlling size, shape and composition, or from the complexity during synthesis. Catalyst reconstruction under reaction conditions has been observed during many electrocatalytic reactions, and the structural differences between pre-catalysts (as-prepared) and true catalysts (reconstructed) are governed by applied potentials, electrolyte compositions, solvent, reactants, intermediates and products [ 32–43 ]. This phenomenon suggests electrochemical synthesis as an alternative approach for the production of highly efficient catalysts. Electrochemical synthesis is featured with simple operation, low cost, easy manipulation of synthesis variables (e.g., pH, additive, electrolyte, temperature, potential, current) as well as high degrees of freedom in tuning morphologies and compositions of catalytic materials [ 44–47 ]. Furthermore, the electrochemically synthesized materials are usually electrically conductive or grown on conductive substrates, so that they can directly serve as candidate catalysts or integrated electrodes for electrocatalytic applications. A comparison in Table 1 indicates that electrochemical synthesis method shows many advantages compared with other physical and chemical synthesis methods. The method of electrochemical synthesis can be traced back to over one century ago when Fritz Haber observed the formation of metal nanoparticles when applying a negative potential to metal wires [ 48 ]. This electrochemical phenomenon was further recognized and confirmed as cathodic corrosion with the aid of modern characterization techniques for nanoscience and nanotechnology in 2011 by Koper and co-workers [ 49 ]. Later on, cathodic corrosion has evolved into an important method for nanoparticle synthesis and catalyst modification [ 50 ]. Apart from the historical method, many other electrochemical methods have been reported and used for the rational design and synthesis of nanostructured catalysts. The present review article will summarize main electrochemical synthesis methods, classify electrochemically synthesized catalysts in terms of morphology, and highlight their applications in the above-mentioned energy-related electrocatalytic reactions (Fig. 1 ). We will exemplify the unique electrocatalytic properties of representative catalysts synthesized by specific electrochemical methods. Since this study mainly focuses on electrochemical synthesis methods for the preparation of catalytic materials, the fundamental principles and mechanistic understanding of electrocatalytic reactions of interest will not be discussed in details. Interested readers are suggested to refer to previous excellent reviews [ 51–58 ]. 2 Experimental methods for electrochemical synthesis of catalytic materials Catalytic materials can be electrochemically prepared under potential/current control, initially starting from either metal salts via bottom-up synthesis or bulk metals via top-down synthesis. For given metals, the structure, composition and morphology of target catalysts depend on many parameters such as electrolyte, pH and additive, as well as the way how potential/current is applied. In this section, we briefly introduce the fundamentals of electrochemical synthesis and several important experimental methods that are used to produce various nanostructured catalysts for electrocatalytic reactions. 2.1 Fundamentals of electrochemical synthesis The unique feature of electrochemical synthesis is to apply potentials/currents to drive the reduction of metal salts, rather than using a wide variety of reducing agents in wet-chemical synthesis. The nucleation and growth that control the structure, composition and morphology can be precisely tuned by applied potentials/currents. Fig. 2 shows commonly used procedures of applying currents and potentials. Galvanostatic (potentiostatic) mode refers to continuously drive an oxidation/reduction process for material formation or degradation at a constant current (potential), as shown in Figs. 2(a),(b). Cyclic voltammetry, a potentiodynamic technique, is featured with many cycles in each of which the working electrode potential is ramped linearly with time (Fig. 2(c)). Successive oxidation-reduction treatments could stimulate crystal growth in preferred directions and thus form shaped nanostructures [ 37 ]. Square-wave potential pulse refers to apply periodical potentials to working electrodes with specific frequencies (Fig. 2(d)). The pulse provokes rather complex perturbations that affect adsorption/desorption behaviors occurring at electrode/electrolyte interfaces, thus offering opportunities to control the structures and properties of electrochemically grown materials [ 59–61 ]. This technique also shows its unique ability to in situ regenerate catalysts under reaction conditions [ 62,63 ]. In a few cases, square-wave current pulse technique is used as well [ 64,65 ]. Since cyclic voltammetry and square-wave potential pulse techniques exhibit unprecedent tunability to tailor catalysts on demand, an electrochemical procedure coupling cyclic voltammetry and square-wave potential pulse techniques (Fig. 2(e)) has been demonstrated in the synthesis of shaped nanocrystals [ 66 ]. While most studies use direct current as electric input mode, alternating current could also find its place in some cases where potential amplitude and frequency are two important parameters in governing size and shape of metal nanostructures [ 67 ]. In addition, electrochemical synthesis under extreme conditions with ultrahigh voltages and/or ultrahigh currents are also explored [ 68,69 ]. Besides electrochemical procedures, similar to the wet-chemical synthesis, the compositions and properties of used electrolytes also play a vital role in electrochemical synthesis. For instance, the concentration and identity of electrolyte anions as well as alkali metal cations affect the onset potential and surface morphology in cathodic corrosion [ 50,70 ], while halide ions are known to act as structure directing agents and probably favor the formation of specific facets by their strong adsorption and interaction with metal surfaces [ 71 ]. Following the role of halide ions, organic additives such as ethylene diamine tetraacetic acid (EDTA), polyethylene glycol (PEG) and sodium dodecylbenzenesulfonate (SDBS) and 3,5-diamino-1,2,4-triazole (DAT) are used as common structure directing agents [ 72,73 ]. However, unlike the use of halide ions which can produce surfactant-free and clean nanostructures, the capped organic additives have to be removed before serving as catalysts in most cases. Catalysts are usually electrochemically grown and/or deposited on conductive substrates such as glassy carbon, carbon paper, fluorine-doped tin oxide (FTO) and metal foils/foams. These substrates do not only act as supports for active metal nanostructures, but also provide material sources for nanostructure synthesis and stabilize meta-stable structures [ 37,74 ]. Nevertheless, the selected substrates should be structurally stable under reaction conditions and be inactive in most cases. 2.2 Experimental methods of electrochemical synthesis While there are versatile methods by adjusting various synthesis parameters, herein we introduce several experimental methods that are widely used in electrochemical synthesis. 2.2.1 Electrodeposition Electrodeposition, also known as electroplating, is a versatile and scalable electrochemical process that allows the deposition of metal ions on electrode surfaces (to produce metal or metal oxide nanostructures) through chemical reactions governed by applied current or potential. This powerful method has produced most of the electrochemically synthesized catalysts from single atoms, clusters and nanoparticles to dendritic structures and thin films [ 46,47,75–77 ]. In general, electrodeposition of a species (typically reduction of a metal cation to a solid metal) occurs at a potential below the equilibrium (Nernst) potential. In other words, an overpotential is required. However, underpotential deposition (UPD) that occurs at a potential less negative than the equilibrium potential, is possible when one metal deposits onto another metal. UPD is a method to determine electrochemically active surface areas of metal nanostructures, but can be also used for the synthesis of catalysts in which a sub-monolayer of surface adatoms with precisely controlled coverage can be deposited on substrates [ 78 ]. 2.2.2 Cathodic corrosion Cathodic corrosion is an electrochemical process that etches metal electrodes at negative potentials. This process takes place in an electrolyte containing highly concentrated strongly irreducible cationic species under highly cathodic potential. The mechanism involves the formation of negatively charged metal anions that move away from electrode surface and are oxidized back to metal atoms that redeposit onto native electrode surface or nucleate in solution to form nanoparticles [ 49 ]. Cathodic corrosion offers a unique way to produce milligrams of surface-clean nanomaterials (e.g., nanoparticles, alloy nanoparticles, oxide materials) in minutes or hours, without using capping agents [ 50 ]. Moreover, materials obtained under the highly non-equilibrium conditions of cathodic corrosion are rich of low-coordination sites and defects that are required as active sites for many reactions. 2.2.3 Electrochemical dealloying Dealloying, also known as selective leaching, is a process during which one metal component dissolves from an alloy or composite, along with the presence of micro- or nano-sized pores and surface defects. The benefit of electrochemical versus chemical dealloying is its ability to control the process more precisely, via dealloying potentials applied through specific electrochemical techniques like cyclic voltammetry. Electrochemical dealloying as a post-treatment is a facile method to improve the electrocatalytic performance of alloy and intermetallic nanoparticles originally prepared by wet-chemical methods [ 79,80 ]. 2.2.4 Galvanic replacement Galvanic replacement reaction consists of a redox process between a metal, serving as a sacrificial template, and ions of another metal in solution. It is driven by a favorable difference in the reduction potentials of the two metals. The template metal will be oxidized and dissolved while the ions of the second metal will be reduced and deposited onto the template surface. This method is able to synthesis bimetallic and hollow nanomaterials with ultrathin shells in single reaction steps and in short reaction times. The molar ratio between reactants and the geometry of sacrificial templates are two important synthesis parameters. Since the seminal work in 2002 by Xia and co-workers [ 81 ], this simple reaction has been employed to generate a wide variety of metal nanostructures with tunable composition, morphology and internal structures [ 82,83 ]. 2.2.5 Electrochemical exfoliation Electrochemical exfoliation of layered bulk materials involves the utilization of a liquid electrolyte and an applied potential (anodic or cathodic) to drive structural expansion to form atomically thin two-dimensional materials in a scalable fashion. Anodic exfoliation proceeds by the intercalation of anions in aqueous electrolytes into layered bulk anode under positive bias. Cathodic exfoliation is usually conducted in organic solutions containing alkali metal ions or quaternary ammonium cations under highly negative charge. Tuning electrolyte composition or applied potentials/currents can manipulate the thickness, defect density, oxygen content and electrical conductivity of the produced two-dimensional materials [ 84 ]. 2.2.6 Electrochemical modification Electrochemical modification of surfaces is an extensively used method to functionalize catalysts/electrodes. An oxidation or reduction process driven by applied potentials/currents would result in the precise modification of electrode surfaces in terms of oxidation state, morphology and defects. The simplicity in applying potentials/currents is favorable for the in-situ modification or regeneration of catalysts during electrocatalytic reactions [ 62,63 ]. Electrografting that attaches organic layers onto solid conducting substrates is another important method for surface modification [ 85 ]. The electrochemically grafted organic ligands can serve as a co-catalyst to tune the local reaction environment near active metal surfaces by steric and electronic effects [ 86 ]. 3 Electrochemically synthesized catalysts and their applications in energy catalysis As of now, the above-introduced electrochemical methods as well as others have been vastly applied in the synthesis of catalysts for energy catalysis, especially electrocatalysis. These catalysts differ from each other in terms of size, shape, morphology, composition and so on. In this section, we classify them into different groups and demonstrate the unique role of electrochemical methods in shaping their specific structures and properties. Representative examples of electrochemically synthesized catalysts showing strong structure-performance correlations are discussed in details. 3.1 Single atom catalysts The synthesis of single atom catalysts with precise coordination is a challenging task. While conventional chemical synthesis predominates the preparation of single atom catalysts [ 87 ], electrochemical synthesis has recently been reported and shows great promise. Zeng and co-workers [ 88 ] reported electrodeposition as a universal strategy to fabricate single atom catalysts. Over 30 catalysts were obtained from cathodic or anodic deposition by varying metal precursors and supports in a standard three-electrode cell (Fig. 3 ). Potential cycles with a scan rate of 5 mV·s−1 were applied to the cell, with a range of −0.4–0.1 V in cathodic deposition and a range of 1.1–1.8 V in anodic deposition. Interestingly, single atom catalysts of the same metal by cathodic and anodic deposition show different electronic structures, with the anodically deposited metal single atoms exhibiting higher oxidation state. Moreover, the anodically deposited catalysts are more active for OER while those obtained from cathodic deposition are promising candidates for HER catalysts. With the same technique, they further synthesized Fe single atoms anchored on porous carbon, with a dominance of Fe3+ oxidation state in the as-prepared sample [ 89 ]. Under OER conditions, highly active Fe4+ centers were in situ generated, resulting in a very high turnover frequency (TOF) of 0.62 s−1 at an overpotential of 0.35 V. Chen and co-workers synthesized Cu single atoms anchored on sulfur sites of doped graphite foam via a UPD method [ 90 ]. The UPD of Cu was conducted in H-cell filled with an aqueous solution of 5 mmol·L−1 CuSO4 and 0.1 mol·L−1 H2SO4 under potentiostatic conditions. This system is also featured with the convenience for qualitative and quantitative analysis of the as-synthesized catalysts. Xia and co-workers [ 91 ] used UPD to deposit non-noble metal (e.g., Cu) single atoms onto the chalcogen atoms of transition metal dichalcogenides, followed by galvanic displacement with more-noble metals (e.g., Pt). This site-specific electrodeposition automatically terminated the formation of metallic bonding and ensured the dispersion of metal at the atomic scale. It has been observed that Pt species (e.g., Pt2+ or Pt4+ in acidic media) are dissolved from the Pt counter electrode into electrolyte and redeposited onto the cathode when the potential exceeds the dissolution onset potential (1.1 V in acidic media) for Pt [ 92 ]. This detrimental effect of Pt dissolution has recently been employed to synthesis Pt single atom catalysts [ 93–95 ]. In such a synthesis procedure, potential cycling was performed with a Pt foil as counter electrode, a reference electrode and the substrate materials as working electrode. If a single atom catalyst was used as the substrate, it was likely to produce dual-metal single atom catalysts [ 95 ]. This process could also be simply achieved by a Pt electroplating method in which an external direct current power source applied a voltage difference between the Pt foil and the substrate [ 93 ]. This method is likely applied to the synthesis of other transition metal single atom catalysts, but acquiring good atomic dispersion might be difficult. Yao and co-workers [ 96 ] reported the synthesis of Ni single atom catalysts by applying an electrochemical activation process to Ni nanoparticles encapsulated in graphene layers (Ni@C). Both constant-potential activation and cyclic-potential activation processes could effectively transform Ni@C into Ni single atoms anchored on carbon matrix which showed highly efficient HER performance with a high exchange current density of 1.2 mA·cm−2 and impressive durability. The direct pyrolysis of metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) is a classical way to prepare carbon-supported single atom catalysts, but it suffers from long synthesis time and high cost. Hong and co-workers developed the cheap synthesis of carbon-supported single atom catalysts through rapid carbonization of MOFs using high voltage [ 69 ]. This was achieved by an electric flash strategy via applying either continuous plasma arc (PA method) or intermittent spark pulse (SP method) under high voltage (Fig. 4 ). Continuous plasma arc resulted in nitrogen-doped carbon ultrathin nanosheets, while an intermittent spark pulse produced carbon hollow nanospheres via blasting effect. Both processes could prepare gram-scale Co single atom catalysts within only one minute. 3.2 Spherical nanoparticles Nanoparticles are the most common catalyst morphology, as they have a high surface area to volume ratio, unique size and shape effects, as well as the convenience in practical application after being loaded onto appropriate supports. A large range of metal, alloy, oxide and core-shell nanoparticles can be synthesized electrochemically in a fast and clean way. Koper and co-workers treated a Pt wire by applying a potential of –10 V for 1000 s in 10 mol·L−1 NaOH [ 49 ]. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images showed that the whole surface of the wire was covered by uniform nanoparticles (Fig. 5 (a)). By applying a nonoxidizing alternating-current voltage in the same solution, the whole bulk wire was decomposed in minutes to form a black suspension of nanoparticles that could be transferred to a supporting electrode for practical use. These Pt nanoparticles with high surface area and increased density of low-coordinated surface sites showed a superior catalytic activity for the oxidation of CO and methanol over a state-of-the-art commercial Pt catalyst. The size and shape of Pt nanoparticles can be tuned by electrolyte composition and concentration [ 70,97,98 ]. The simple, clean, fast and top-down cathodic corrosion method also applies to the production of nanoparticles of other metals such as Pd, Au, Ag, Cu, Rh, Ir, Ni, Sn and Pb [ 70,99–101 ]. If a bulk alloy electrode is used in this method, it is likely to obtain alloy (e.g., PtRh, PtNi, AuCu, FeCo) nanoparticles that retain the composition and crystal structure of the starting bulk alloy [ 102 ]. However, this is evidently challenged by the synthesis of nanoparticles of many alloys that are not stable in the bulk phase. Rodriguez and co-workers [ 103 ] developed a modification of the cathodic corrosion method by taking advantage of the nonequilibrium synthesis conditions, namely, forming a surface alloy by using the main metal as a bulk electrode and leaving the second metal present in the electrolyte during the synthesis. With this strategy, they demonstrated the successful preparation of binary PtBi and PtPb nanoparticles with different compositions. Since an alternating-current voltage had to be applied to decompose the cathodically corroded Pt wire in Koper's seminal work [ 49 ], Bandarenka and co-workers directly applied a higher alternating current voltage and added carbon black in the solution to prepare carbon-supported metal or alloy nanoparticles [ 67,104,105 ]. For instance, they used a sinusoidal potential of ±10 V vs. Pt pseudo-reference (frequency 200 Hz) to induce the erosion of the Pt wires to produce carbon supported ∼3 nm Pt nanoparticles (Fig. 5(c)). The ORR activity exceeded that of a commercial Pt/C catalyst, ∼2.7 times in terms of specific activity (∼1.62 mA·cm−2 Pt at 0.9 V vs. RHE) and ∼1.7 times in terms of mass activity (∼712 mA·mg−1 Pt) [ 104 ]. A simple electrodeposition process could also produce small and highly dispersed metal nanoparticles. Foord and co-workers conducted a very comprehensive study on the early stage nucleation and growth of Pd nanoparticles over a Au(111) textured substrate [ 106 ]. By applying a constant potential, Pd nanoparticles with an average size of 2−5 nm were synthesized and they became smaller with higher overpotentials (Fig. 5(b)). The as-obtained Pd nanoparticles showed 35-fold higher activity for ethanol oxidation than that of commercial Pd/C catalysts that were usually prepared by wet-chemical synthesis [ 107 ]. Strasser and co-workers did substantial studies on the electrochemical dealloying of Pt-based alloys by potential cycling treatments in strongly acidic medium, resulting in the formation of Pt-rich shell, core-shell Pt-M nanoparticles that could effectively improve electrocatalytic activity for the ORR in fuel cells [ 79,108,109 ]. Depending on particle size, these dealloyed nanoparticles could exhibit single core-shell, multiple cores-shell, as well as surface pits and nanoscale pore structures [ 109 ]. Abruña and co-workers [ 80 ] conducted electrochemical dealloying on ordered Cu3Pt intermetallic nanoparticles which also led to a PtCu@Pt core-shell structure (Fig. 5(d)). In contrast, chemical leaching (by immersing in 1 mol·L−1 HNO3 for 2 days under continuous magnetic stirring) produced a spongy structure with ordered structures not being preserved [ 110 ]. 3.3 Shape-controlled nanoparticles Shaped-controlled nanoparticles are of significant importance for many different electrocatalytic reactions, since the shape of the nanoparticles essentially determines their surface structure (i.e., surface atomic arrangement and coordination) [ 111 ]. They are ideal model catalysts to study the structure sensitivity of a given reaction for building up correct correlations between surface structure and electrocatalytic performance [ 112 ]. One of the challenges hindering correct structure-performance relationships is surface cleanness, as most of synthesis methods for shape-controlled nanoparticles use capping agents that are difficult to be fully removed [ 113 ]. While capping agents are sometimes used for specific purposes in a few cases [ 72,73,114 ], electrochemical methods are likely to synthesize various shape-controlled nanoparticles with clean surfaces. High-index crystal facets generally exhibit much higher catalytic activity than that of the most common stable facets, as they have a higher density of atomic steps, edges and kinks which usually show distinct ability for adsorbing reaction intermediates and facilitate bond breaking and bond forming during a chemical reaction [ 115 ]. However, the synthesis of shape-controlled nanoparticles with high-index facets is quite difficult, because crystal growth rates in the direction perpendicular to a high-index plane are usually much faster than those along the normal direction of a low-index plane. Sun and co-workers developed a route for shape-controlled synthesis of tetrahexahedral (THH) Pt nanoparticles with high yield (>90%) through a square-wave potential (upper potential: 1.2 V, lower potential: –0.2 to –0.1 V, frequency: 10 Hz), starting from Pt nanospheres (∼750 nm) electrodeposited on glassy carbon (Fig. 6(a) ) [ 116 ]. The size of the THH Pt nanoparticles was controlled by varying the growth time. Growing for 10, 30, 40, 50 min could produce THH Pt nanoparticles with sizes of 53, 100, 126 and 144 nm, respectively (Fig. 6(b)). Furthermore, these THH Pt nanoparticles with high-energy surfaces are thermally stable even at ∼800 °C, without losing the shape and facets (Fig. 6(c)), and exhibited much improved (up to 400%) catalytic activity for oxidation of small of ethanol and formic acid compared with the untreated electrodeposited Pt nanospheres. However, the smallest THH Pt nanoparticles obtained by this procedure have a size of ∼20 nm, which severely impedes their practical applications. The same group further developed an electrochemically seed-mediated method that was able to synthesize small tetrahexahedral Pt nanoparticles (1.5−9.5 nm) supported on graphene [ 117 ]. Anyway, since the report of this seminal work, the Sun's group [ 118–121 ] has applied this method to the synthesis of many other shape-controlled metal (e.g., Pd, Rh) and alloy (e.g., PdRh) nanoparticles. Recently, using Bragg coherent X-ray diffraction imaging (BCDI) technique, Richard and co-workers [ 122 ] studied the strain in the surface vicinity of THH Pt nanoparticles at the single-particle level and observed a facet-dependent compressive strain build-up close to facets and edges. As strain effects in shaped-controlled nanostructures play a vital role in tuning activity and selectivity of many important electrocatalytic reactions such as CO2RR and ORR [ 123,124 ], herein we expect BCDI as a promising method for strain engineering in the synthesis of shape-controlled nanoparticles with high-index facets. Galvanic replacement is a simple method to produce core-shell or hollow shaped bi-metallic nanoparticles, starting from polyhedron nanoparticles synthesized either electrochemically or wet-chemically [ 82 ]. When two or more kinds of facets are present on the surface of the initial polyhedron nanoparticles, galvanic replacement can proceed with facet selectivity, providing a way to engineer the shape of final nanostructures. A classic example was the galvanic replacement of Ag cuboctahedrons, enclosed by six (100) and eight (111) facets, with HAuCl4. The dissolution of Ag atoms began from (100) facets, while the deposition of Au atoms occurred on (111) facets, resulting in the formation of the nanocages produced with uniform pores with identical size and shape located at eight corners [ 125 ]. In addition to facet, galvanic replacement was also found to be promoted by bromine (Br−) ions that led to the selective initiation of galvanic replacement from (100) facets of shaped-controlled Pd nanoparticles likely by their preferential adsorption. The simultaneous dissolution of Pd atoms from (100) facets and deposition of the resultant Pt atoms on (111) facets produced Pd-Pt bimetallic nanocubes with a concave structure. The Pd-Pt concave nanocubes with only 3.4 wt% Pt exhibited four times as active as commercial Pt/C catalyst for ORR [ 126 ]. It has been reported that such galvanic replacement process over shape-controlled nanoparticles with high-index facets (e.g., high-index faceted Pd@Pt), is likely caused by the deconstruction of initial polyhedron morphology due to the fast dissolution of high energy surfaces. In addition, the galvanic replacement is also able to synthesize shape-controlled metal oxide nanoparticles such as hollow box-shaped Mn3O4/γ-Fe2O3 nanoparticles formed by the reaction of square prism-shaped Mn3O4 nanoparticles with iron(II) perchlorate [ 127 ]. Experimental and theoretical studies on single crystal surfaces indicate that Cu(100) facets are favorable for the production of multicarbon (C2+) products from CO2RR owing to its improved ability for C–C coupling (e.g., via *CO dimerization) [ 128,129 ]. Cubic-shaped Cu nanoparticles (Cu nanocubes) enclosed with Cu(100) facets are ideal platform to verify the above finding in real catalysts. Electrodeposition with potential cycling has been demonstrated as an effective way to synthesize Cu nanocubes at the absence of any surfactant and reducing agent [ 37,130 ]. In such cases, chloride ions (Cl−) in the precursor solution likely work as an inorganic structure directing agent [ 131 ]. Using liquid cell TEM that allows to directly image nanostructures in a liquid environment with the high spatial resolution of a TEM, Roldan Cuenya and co-workers [ 132 ] demonstrated how Cu nanocubes are formed from copper sulfate solutions during direct electrochemical synthesis. There were two key parameters for the nanocube formation: the presence of Cl− ions in the electrolyte and the alternating potentials at which the deposited non-cubic nanoparticles dissolved, but cubic ones did not (Fig. 7(a) ). They further studied the influence of synthesis parameters required for the Cu nanocubes electrodeposited over glassy carbon substrates [ 130 ]. The concentration of Cl− ions controlled the size, shape and coverage, while the ratio of the reduction versus oxidation time and number of potential cycles could be used to further tune the size. In addition to the above bottom-up electrodeposition method, electrochemically oxidizing and reducing an electropolished Cu foil in an electrolyte containing Cl− ions with potential cycles could grow Cu nanocubes directly on the surface of the Cu foil [ 66,74,133 ]. In such cases, no Cu salt was added into the electrolyte and the surface layer of the treated Cu foil formed nanocubes via chloride- and potential-induced nanostructuring effect. Interestingly, Cu nanocubes produced in the two ways showed quite different catalytic selectivity towards CO2RR. As shown in Fig. 7(b), carbon supported Cu nanocubes behaved like a Cu foil producing more methane than ethylene, while Cu nanocubes grown on Cu foils produced much improved ethylene over methane [ 37,74 ]. This apparent support effect was likely attributed to the stabilized Cu+ species by the interaction between Cu nanocubes and underlying Cu foils. Inspired by halide effects on CO2RR [ 134,135 ], the Roldan Cuenya's group [ 71 ] further studied the role of bromine and iodide in reconstructuring Cu surfaces, and found that the iodine-modified needle-like Cu electrode showed the highest partial current density and a Faradaic efficiency of 80% for the generation of C2+ products (Fig. 7(c)). Operando high energy resolution fluorescence detected X-ray adsorption near edge structure (HERFD-XANES) spectroscopy measurements indicated the presence of Cu+ species coordinated with residual oxygen and iodine species under CO2RR conditions. The performances of these catalysts synthesized by the electrolyte-driven nanostructuring strategy suggested that Cu+ species rather than Cu(100) facets could play a more important role in determining activity and selectivity of CO2RR. The positive effect of residual iodine species in Cu catalysts was further verified by assembling gas diffusion electrode used in a flow cell using a Cu-CuI composite catalyst [ 136 ]. Wang and co-workers [ 137 ] also grew Cu nanocubes by modifying electropolished Cu foils, by a metal ion (Cu2+) cycling method that is similar to a battery galvanostatic (10 mA·cm−2 in this work) charging-discharging procedure. The surface of Cu foils was roughened after 10 galvanostatic cycles and gradually evolved into cubic shape with smooth (100) surfaces after 100 cycles. Compared with pristine Cu foil, the 100-cycled Cu nanocube catalyst showed improved CO2RR performance and presented a 6-fold improvement in the Faradaic efficiency ratio of C2+/C1, with the highest C2+ Faradaic efficiency of over 60%. 3.4 Two-dimensional nanostructures The large specific surface area and abundant edges of two-dimensional nanostructures offer numerous electrochemically active sites [ 138,139 ]. In this context, thin films with a thickness of mono-atomic layer to nanometers can be grown on conducting substrates via electrodeposition. Moffat and co-workers developed a self-terminating rapid electrodeposition process for controlled growth of Pt monolayer films on Au(111) substrates [ 140 ]. Pt deposition was quenched by self-terminating effect of a saturated underpotential deposited H (Hupd) layer, leading to a high coverage of two-dimensional Pt islands. When applying pulsed potentials to periodically oxidize the Hupd layer, sequential deposition of discrete two-dimensional Pt layers with desired thickness was achieved. The process could be considered as a wet ALD technique. Jin and co-workers [ 141 ] demonstrated the synthesis of CoFe hydroxide nanosheets with a thickness of 20–30 nm grown on graphite substrates via electrodeposition using a solution containing 6 mmol·L−1 Co(NO3)2 and 6 mmol·L−1 Fe(NO3)3 at a constant negative potential. The accompanied reduction of NO3 − ions slowly generated hydroxide at the graphite surface, which could increase the solution pH to facilitate the precipitation of amorphous bimetallic hydroxide. Due to the amorphous nature and the high electrochemical surface area, the as-synthesized amorphous CoFe hydroxide nanosheets showed excellent OER performance comparable to other state-of-the-art catalysts. Apart from direct synthesis of nanosheets, it is also likely to electrochemically activate and transform pre-synthesized nanosheets. Zheng and co-workers [ 142 ] demonstrated that Ni-thiolate polymer (Ni-BDT) nanosheets, prepared with Ni(OH)2 nanosheets as the template and 1,4-benzenedithiol (BDT) as the ligand, can be electrochemically in situ converted into ultrathin metal Ni nanosheets with trace sulfur species (S ad σ−) adsorbed on the surface. This nanosheet catalyst exhibited a HER current density of 10 mA·cm−2 at an overpotential of only 80 mV, attributed to the presence of the Ni0-S ad σ− interface (Fig. 8 ). Another important application of electrochemical synthesis is to prepare two-dimensional layered materials via electrochemical exfoliation [ 84,143 ]. The method has been applied in the exfoliation of graphite [ 143 ], black phosphorus [ 144 ], group IVA and VA metals [ 145 ], transition-metal dichalcogenides [ 146 ], graphitic carbon nitride [ 146 ], transition metal oxides [ 146 ], metal-organic framework nanosheets [ 147 ] and 2D transition metal carbides, carbonitrides and nitrides (MXene) [ 148 ]. An interesting example was the controllable synthesis of few-layer Bi subcarbonate nanosheets through electrochemical exfoliation [ 149 ]. They exhibited high Faradaic efficiency and current density towards CO2RR to formate thanks to their two-dimensional structure and the co-existence of Bi subcarbonate and metallic Bi under reaction conditions. 3.5 Three-dimensional nanostructures The electrochemically synthesized three-dimensional nanostructures include films, dendric and hierarchically porous structures as well as nanowire and nanotube arrays, the majority of which could be prepared by electrodeposition by tuning different synthesis parameters [ 75–77,150–159 ]. In general, the synthesis of such large structures (usually at the micrometer scale) with locally nanometer scale features is relatively easy and does not require very precise control. While small nanostructures with a few nanometers are preferred in many heterogeneous reactions owing to remarkable size effects, such three-dimensional large nanostructures with still high surface areas performs very reactive as well for reactions like OER and CO2RR over specific catalyst systems [ 75,152 ]. Cheng and co-workers [ 160 ] proposed an anion intercalation enhanced electrodeposition strategy for the synthesis of metal hydroxides/oxides via reduction of oxyacid anions. The key of this strategy was using graphitic substrates that were particularly beneficial in cathodic electrodeposition owing to the graphene interlayer accommodating anions. The authors adopted a two-step deposition (Fig. 9(a) ). NO3 − ions were inserted into the graphitic lattice via electrostatic attraction under an applied positive potential. After that, a negative potential was applied to deposit metal ions and the cathodic reduction of NO3 − ions. The latter process produced hydroxide ions (increased local pH near electrode surface), and thus kinetically promoted the deposition of metal hydroxides as well as the coprecipitation of bi-metallic or multi-metallic hydroxides in some cases (Fig. 9(b)). This method was effective in the synthesis of a wide variety of metal (including IIA, IIB, IIIB, VIB, and VIII elements) hydroxides/oxides. The co-electrodeposited NiCeO x H y /graphite, with nanocrystalline CeO2 and amorphous Ni(OH)2, showed a low OER overpotential (177 mV@10 mA·cm−2) and an excellent long-term stability of over 300 hours at an industrially-relevant current density of 1 A·cm−2 (Fig. 9(c)). In situ Raman and operando XRD unraveled that the integration of Ce facilitated the formation of catalytically active γ-NiOOH enclosed with (003) facets. When electrochemical synthesis combines with other methods such as combinatorial chemistry and combinatorial phase exploration [ 161,162 ], it is likely to rationally design complicated catalyst systems. Nath and co-workers synthesized quaternary mixed-metal selenide compositions incorporating Ni-Fe-Co via combinatorial electrodeposition over Au-coated glass substrates by exploring the ternary phase diagram of Ni-Fe-Co systems [ 163 ]. Mapping of the OER catalytic activity as a function of catalyst composition indicated that the highest catalytic performance was exhibited by (Ni0.25Fe0.68Co0.07)3Se4, close to the AB2Se4 phase, with an overpotential of 0.23 V at 10 mA·cm−2 and a good stability exceeding 8 h. Dynamic hydrogen bubble template (DHBT), with hydrogen bubbles concurrently produced by HER during electrodeposition, is a promising method to fabricate three-dimensional highly porous nanostructures (i. g., metal foams, dendritic structures) [ 164,165 ]. Wang and co-workers [ 166 ] synthesized three-dimensional Cu-Sn catalysts supported on Cu foam with tunable Cu/Sn ratios by a simple DHBT co-electrodeposition technique. The applied deposition current density was as high as 4 A·cm−2, which was very important to produce abundant hydrogen bubbles as template. The as-obtained CuSn catalyst had a hierarchical Sn-Cu core and a SnO x shell. Similar method was also used for synthesizing Cu-In catalysts [ 167 ]. These electrodeposited Cu-based catalysts powder was then exfoliated from the native Cu foams and incorporated into gas diffusion electrodes that could afford industrial current densities for electrocatalytic reactions. The Sn2.7Cu catalyst achieved a high current density of 406.7 mA·cm−2 with C1 Fardaic efficiency of 98% at –0.7 V vs. RHE for CO2RR [ 166 ]. The reconstructed Sn/SnO x interface under reaction conditions promoted formate and suppressed the competing HER. Broekmann and co-workers further used gas diffusion electrodes as the substrates for DHBT electrodeposition followed by thermal annealing. The as-synthesized three-dimensional dendritic Bi oxide foams underwent potential-dependent transition from Bi2O3 to metallic Bi and exhibited excellent formate selectivity with Faradaic efficiencies never falling below 90% within an extended potential window [ 168 ]. The morphology of metal catalysts is closely correlated with their geometric and electronic structures which intrinsically determine catalytic performances [ 169 ]. Electrochemical synthesis is also used to prepare catalytic materials with controlled geometric and electronic structures at the atomic level. For instance, grain boundaries with specific atomic geometry are considered as active sites for CO2RR over oxide-derived metals [ 170,171 ]. Sun and co-workers [ 172 ] synthesized nanotwinned Ag with highly dense twin boundaries (~10 nm in width) via a pulsed current density of 1 A·cm−2. The width and density of twin boundaries were tuned from 10 to 730 nm and from 0.3 to 1.5 × 104 cm−1, respectively. The most active Ag catalyst exhibited a Faradaic efficiency up to 92% at −1.0 V and a TOF of 127 s−1 for CO production. The Cu oxidation state plays a vital role in C–C coupling for C2+ production during CO2RR [ 173 ]. Electrochemistry provides a way to precisely control the oxidation state by applying specific potentials as suggested by Pourbaix diagram of metals. Velasco-Velez and co-workers [ 174 ] followed the dynamic changes in the complex electronic structure of electrochemically prepared Cu catalysts (with an oxidation state of Cu0, Cu+, and Cu2+) during preparation and reaction using combined advanced X-ray spectroscopy and in situ microreactors. The control in electronic structures were also found in electrochemically synthesized single atom catalysts by Zeng and co-workers [ 88 ], with the anodically deposited metal single atoms exhibiting higher oxidation state. 3.6 Catalyst modification and regeneration Electrochemistry also provides a simple, accurate and controlled method to precisely modify catalysts at the atomic level. Strasser and co-workers presented a surface-electrochemical synthesis strategy that modified a polycrystalline Cu surface by a sub- to one-single monolayer (ML) electrodeposited Pb adatoms via UPD technique which was able to precisely control the coverage of adatoms [ 78 ]. The trace amount of Pb surface adatoms boosted the formation of formate from CO2RR while effectively suppressing HER, resulting in the highest ratio (∼10) of formate/H2 production rate over the 0.78 ML Pb/Cu catalyst (Fig. 10 ). The presence of these sub-monolayer Pd adatoms induced strong electronic effects which tuned the chemisorption of reactive intermediates. Sargent and co-workers [ 86 ] functionalized catalyst surfaces by a library of organic molecules via electro-dimerization of arylpyridiniums on copper. The adhered molecules facilitated the stabilization of linearly adsorbed *CO intermediates and prompted its further reduction to ethylene. With this strategy tuning local environment near catalyst surface, an excellent CO2RR performance was achieved with an ethylene Faradaic efficiency of 72% at a partial current density of 230 mA·cm−2 in a flow cell with neutral electrolytes. In situ reconstruction under reaction conditions is a common phenomenon in heterogeneous electrocatalysis [ 3,39 ]. While the formation of catalytically active structures via electrochemical activation of a pre-catalyst has been observed in some catalyst systems [ 40,42,142 ], many structural changes would lead to catalyst deactivation over a longer time scale [ 34,175–177 ]. In such cases, a simple electrochemical treatment likely regenerates the deactivated catalyst. For instance, Pd nanoparticles tend to suffer from CO poisoning during CO2RR and the production of formate decreases very fast with elevated overpotentials [ 178 ]. This issue can be addressed by applying a positive potential for short time to oxidize the accumulated CO periodically, e.g., applying +0.65 V for 15 min after every 2 h reaction at –0.3 V [ 179 ]. However, the reaction has to be stopped during the regeneration step. Pulsed voltammetry procedure with alternating a lower (reduction) potential and an upper (oxidation) potential can significantly simplify the operation process [ 60,180–183 ]. Roldan Cuenya and co-workers [ 63 ] demonstrated the continuous regeneration of Cu+ species and defects by conducting pulsed CO2RR over single crystal Cu surfaces. The upper potential was rationally selected to deal with the reduction of Cu+ specie and the flatting of Cu surfaces (losing defects) either separately or simultaneously, and thus likely decoupled the effects of the two factors. This was also applied to regenerate real catalysts incorporated into gas diffusion electrodes in flow-cell electrolyzers [ 184 ]. Rodriguez and co-workers [ 185 ] used the pulsed voltammetry method to retain the coverage of oxygen species over single crystal Cu surfaces. They found that the production of oxygenates was preferred over the surface with more adsorbed oxygen species under pulsed conditions, in clear contrast to the selective formation of hydrocarbons using cyclic voltammetry and potentiostatic methods. 4 Concluding remarks and perspectives In this review article, we have discussed different electrochemical strategies for the synthesis of high-performance catalytic materials and exemplified the unique catalytic properties of representative electrochemically synthesized catalysts for energy electrocatalysis applications. Electrochemical synthesis is a simple, fast, cost-effective and precisely controlled approach for the preparation of a wide range of catalytically active nanostructures such as single atoms, spherical and shaped nanoparticles, nanosheets, nanowires, core-shell nanostructures, layered nanomaterials, dendritic nanostructures, hierarchically porous nanostructures as well as composite nanostructures. It is likely to synthesize nanoparticles of alloys of which solid-solution alloys are quite unstable under ambient conditions [ 103 ]. It is able to in situ modify and regenerate catalysts under conditions of specific electrocatalytic reactions as well [ 34,63 ]. These catalytic materials are synthesized by adjusting various synthesis parameters, depending on adopted experimental methods including electrodeposition, cathodic corrosion, electrochemical alloying, galvanic replacement, electrochemical exfoliation and electrochemical modification. The versatility and tunability of electrochemical synthesis over other synthesis methods make this method very promising for the rational design of catalytic materials in energy-related applications. Apart from the nanostructures discussed here, electrochemical synthesis also exhibits great advantages in the preparation of many novel catalytic materials such as MOFs [ 186 ] and high-entropy alloys [ 187 ]. More new nanostructures with improved catalytic properties, desired composition and structural features would be designed and prepared electrochemically, in combination with the further development of electrochemical synthesis methods. Currently, the synthesis process is still based on a trial-and-error approach. A viable solution is theory- and modeling-assisted synthesis by predicting the experimental parameters required to prepare desired catalysts, for instance, the electrochemical synthesis of MXenes aided by first-principles approach [ 188 ]. Artificial intelligence and data science may accelerate the screening of synthesis parameters of efficient catalysts. Another solution is to combine the electrochemical synthesis with other methods (e.g, the assistance of photo, microwave, ultrasonic, magnetic field) [ 189,190 ]. Using room temperature ionic liquids and deep eutectic solvents as alternatives to conventional aqueous solutions is a useful strategy to synthesize clean metal nanostructures free of surface hydroxyls [ 191,192 ]. The growth kinetics and formation mechanisms of various nanostructures during electrochemical synthesis are not yet clearly understood. This could rely on the fast development of advanced characterization techniques for solid-liquid interfaces [ 193–197 ]. The nucleation, growth, formation and evolution of nanostructures during electrochemical synthesis has been tracked in situ by liquid cell TEM, electrochemical SEM, scanning electrochemical microscopy (SECM) and soft X-ray coherent diffraction imaging (XCDI) [ 132,198–203 ]. More important, owing to the intrinsically dynamic feature of catalysis, high-surface-energy nanostructures such as shape-controlled nanoparticles tend to lose their original structure and composition under reaction conditions [ 37,204 ]. However, these structural changes are closely related to the initial structures of as-synthesized catalysts and likely overcome via rational synthesis by using appropriate methods and electrochemical conditions. A typical example is the good thermal stability of THH Pt nanoparticles with high index facets [ 116 ]. It is worth to remark that ex situ (periodic) and in situ (continuous) electrochemical regeneration of deactivated catalysts [ 34,63,182,205,206 ] should be paid more attention, as it is a simple but powerful route to extend operation time and it also expands the application of electrochemical synthesis in addition to catalyst preparation. Last but not least, electrochemical synthesis as a unique and useful technique for the preparation and modification of catalysts can be further applied to thermal- and photocatalysis [ 45 ]. Moreover, it is also highly recommended to use this method in the synthesis of nanomaterials for energy storage and conversion applications beyond catalysis [ 44 ]. References 1 R. coredata.dc:description: Electrocatalysis is a process dealing with electrochemical reactions in the interconversion of chemical energy and electrical energy. Precise synthesis of catalytically active nanostructures is one of the key challenges that hinder the practical application of many important energy-related electrocatalytic reactions. Compared with conventional wet-chemical, solid-state and vapor deposition synthesis, electrochemical synthesis is a simple, fast, cost-effective and precisely controllable method for the preparation of highly efficient catalytic materials. In this review, we summarize recent progress in the electrochemical synthesis of catalytic materials such as single atoms, spherical and shaped nanoparticles, nanosheets, nanowires, core-shell nanostructures, layered nanomaterials, dendritic nanostructures, hierarchically porous nanostructures as well as composite nanostructures. Fundamental aspects of electrochemical synthesis and several main electrochemical synthesis methods are discussed. Structure-performance correlations between electrochemically synthesized catalysts and their unique electrocatalytic properties are exemplified using selected examples. We offer the reader with a basic guide to the synthesis of highly efficient catalysts using electrochemical methods, and we propose some research challenges and future opportunities in this field.
